title: Monday, 11th July, 2016

Dear Paul John,

Welcome to the Labour Party. Thank you so much for joining — it's wonderful to have you with us.

The Labour Party always embodies the value of equality, fairness and social justice. By joining us, you are not just joining a political party — you are joining our fight for these values, a fight that doesn't just happen on polling day.

Labour Party members don't just believe in these values, we put them into practice. And the best thing you can do right now is help keep our movement growing. So please share this graphic on Facebook and encourage people you know to join you in our movement — or just give them this link: labour.org.uk/join

11:17 am
PM

Seems sensible

BE

Following the EU referendum in the UK our economists significantly cut their UK and EZ
GDP forecasts. In addition, our rates strategists now forecast US 10y yield to end 2016
at 1.35% and 2017 at 1.5% (down from 2% and 2.3%), the BoE to cut rates by 50bps
and re-start QE, and finally Bund yields to end 2016 at 0.15% (0.5% at end-2017). This
suggests a move back to bond-like stocks that benefit from lower yields. However,
many of those stocks trade at extreme valuations after years of outperformance. We
look to tilt our portfolio towards cheaper defensives and bond-like stocks with more
attractive valuations.

BE

Upgrade Utilities to Overweight from Neutral
Utilities could benefit from lower yields (Figure 2) as well as from the ECB corporate
bond buying program. The sector's defensive characteristics at cheap valuations are
attractive to us now. Finally, the recovery in commodity prices could provide some relief
to the sector. Key Buys are Centrica and Gas Natural.

11:17 am
BE

Here's fig 2.

BE

BE

Cap Goods has outperformed significantly since late 2015 and this was not supported
by improving earnings momentum. The sector valuations now look unattractive to us
and Cap Goods could lose significantly in a scenario of lower yields, slower growth and
high uncertainty. Key Sells: Kone and Sandvik. Key buys: Siemens, Legrand, Hexagon.

11:18 am
BE

Banks – Despite very cheap valuations and extreme gaps between underlying numbers
and performance, a lower yield and slower growth scenario means we can no longer
see catalysts for banks to outperform in the near term. However, we also see limited
downside and hence move the sector to Neutral. Key Buys – Lloyds, ING, Swedbank;
Key Sells – BBVA, Handelsbanken, Standard Chartered, Deutsche Bank. Chemicals –
commodity prices no longer seem to point to earnings pressure and the sector trades at
a discount to other Materials (this has only happened twice in history and short periods
of time). Key Buys – Covestro, Frutarom, Umicore and Wacker; Key Sells – K+S,
Synthomer and Solvay.

BE

All of which is fairly straightforward, really.

Guillaume Gauvillé and team

11:25 am
PM

We expect no growth for luxury goods in 2Q. Burberry kicks off earnings
season on 13 July. We forecast organic growth for the luxury sector to be
the slowest we have seen in the last seven years. First, comps are tougher
than in previous quarters, mainly in Europe and Japan where tourism
spending was strong in 2Q15. Second, geopolitical uncertainties and stock
market volatility continued to impact the 'feel good factor'. Third, the
renminbi depreciation against the euro and the yen has reduced tourism
spending as regional price gaps got narrower

PM

We cut earnings estimates for most of our coverage and reduce our
target prices for LVMH, Tod's and Hugo Boss. The benefit from a
weaker euro has been more than offset by a weaker renminbi and a more
cautious stance on both 2Q/2H organic growth and margins. In particular,
we are cutting EBITDA forecasts for Hugo Boss and Tod's Group by an
average 8% and 6% respectively over 2016-2018e. We wait until the
sterling stabilises before we review our earnings model for Burberry,
although we estimate a 1.30 $/£ rate would add at least another £50m FX
benefit to PBT in FY17 on top of the £50m guidance given in May.

PM

We remain negative on the luxury sector. Market positioning is clearly
bearish on the sector and market-relative underperformance has been
marked in 2Q. However, we think it is too early to be contrarian. We believe
earnings downgrades will continue through 2H. A pick up in momentum in
3Q is highly uncertain and we worry the cost cutting actions may not be
enough to avoid further margin pressure. In this environment, we rely on
LVMH (O/P) and its defensive attributes thanks to its luxury/staples/retail
portfolio. We would be cautious on Richemont (N) due to medium-term
cyclical headwinds.

Dixons Carphone PLC (DC.:LSE): Last: 312.40, down 2.9 (-0.92%), High: 315.90, Low: 304.00, Volume: 3.04m
BE

I think, at the current price, Dixons has erased the value of Carphone. It's back to the level it was pre merger.

BE

Here's Barclays.

11:41 am
BE

Despite a self help story and a credible strategy, DC’s housing market dependant
big ticket items will likely come under pressure in 2H and into FY17. We believe
mobiles will be resilient but TVs and white goods can be a drag on earnings and the
lack of large struggling competitors may temper any material market share gains.
We think the low PE doesn't reflect management's initiatives long term, but in the
next 12 months if earnings momentum turns negative, DC could come under more
pressure. The low FY17 FCF due to store refurbishments and CWS growth
investment, although temporary, may deter investors with shorter term horizons.
Management can flex the cost base if demand is weak, but we think this will be a
last resort so they don't harm growth longer term. DC’s share price has
underperformed the sector since Brexit and now already incorporates negative
prospects near term. Nonetheless, without signs of a stabilization in consumer
confidence, we find it hard to see DC outperforming. We provide a scenario analysis
on DC’s EPS. We expect flat FY17 EPS growth vs. Consensus at +10%. We
downgrade DC to Equal Weight with a PT of 315p from 530p using an average of
10x PE and our DCF methodology.

BE

Reduce FY17 EPS by 11% to 29p and now we are 10% below Bloomberg consensus.
While we keep our Nordics and Southern European profit estimates intact we have
taken a sufficiently cautious stance on the UK with a -3.4% decline in consumer
electronics, half as bad as in the previous recession and flat mobile sales. SWAS add
2pps into sales while the £40m cost synergies can work as a cushion to profitability.
We think our 235p per share downside case is a floor share price. We assign a low
probability to this. We assume consumer electronics sales decline by 8% in line with the
credit crunch era, while mobile sales decline by 5%, never seen before. In such a
scenario management could cut costs for marketing and online delivery options. Our
26p EPS estimate would unlikely get more than 9x.
1Q sales in September could be strong. Management’s positive commentary last
fortnight could mean a strong 1Q and could spark a relief rally. But until then
uncertainty will likely weigh on the shares.

In late June 2015, Mr. James Hirshorn, a member of the Board and partner of Ares Management LLC ("Ares"), was approached by a representative of a large domestic industrial company, which we refer to as "Strategic Bidder A," regarding its potential interest in a transaction with the Company. Mr. Hirshorn informed other members of the Board, including Mr. Michael Clarke, the chief executive officer of the Company, and on July 7, 2015, the Company received an unsolicited, non-binding indication of interest from Strategic Bidder A to acquire the Company in an all cash acquisition at a price of $101.00 per share. The closing price per share of Company common stock on July 7, 2015 was $83.16.

The Board convened a telephonic meeting on July 11, 2015 to consider the unsolicited indication of interest, potential responses and retaining the services of one or more financial and legal advisors. At this meeting, the Board determined to retain Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP ("Weil") as legal counsel in connection with its consideration of a potential transaction and to defer responding to Strategic Bidder A's indication of interest until the Company had engaged and received advice from one or more financial advisors.

The best thing about the US takeover system is the 14d. Without following closely enough, I think the stuff above refers to the United Tech bid leak that ended up in the WSJ.

BE

Worth noting, I guess, that analysts don't completely discount the possibility of a counter.

11:46 am
BE

Here's Jefferies.

BE

Based on what NTK paid for Thomas & Betts (9x EV/EBITDA) and Daikin's acquisition of Goodman (10.6x), historically HVAC companies have been taken out at the 9 - 11x range. That said, we view a takeout multiple in the 8.5 - 9.0x range reasonable for NTK factoring in the non-HVAC businesses. While we wouldn't be surprised if a strategic stepped in and paid a higher price, there is a $50 mil breakup fee, which at a minimum needs to exceed $89.11 / share, and it's been nearly a year since the UTX deal fell apart. NTK has a window shop period through August 6th to find a superior deal.

BE

Oh, the second best thing about the US takeover system is the go-shop. That's cool as well.

11:46 am
BE

Should see good support from shareholder base. We expect the company's shareholders to support the deal, noting Ares, Anchorage, and Gates Capital (68.7% combined interest) have entered into tender and should be in the money with their positions largely built as debt holders from the bankruptcy. The transaction is expected to close on August 31st.

BE

What's not been explained to me is that if Nortek's such a valuable asset, why didn't Melrose shareholders didn't just buy Nortek shares at any time before last week? They would've got them for 38% cheaper.

BE

The Melrose management premium multiplier is quite something.

11:54 am
BE

UBS downgrades to sell as part of a big wrap of the engineering sector.

BE

FX nice. Uncontrollable, unpredictable recession less so.

BE

Low growth and falling ROIC are more important than FX upgrades
We would be incrementally more cautious on the UK engineers. YTD momentum has
been positive, with the UK engineering index up 18% YTD (and stable since the UK
'Leave' vote, outperforming the FTSE 250). We expect consensus EPS upgrades with an
FX tailwind prompting an average 6% lift to our 2017E EPS. However, while there is a
short-term tailwind, a lack of general global growth (which will not likely be helped by
the Leave vote) is more of an issue. We forecast sector ROIC falling to 15-year lows for
the group in 2016. Managers have tried to "buy" growth. In H2 15 we highlighted
growing valuation support for the UK engineering group. However, post the YTD rally,
valuations are back near 15-year absolute highs, and up significantly in relative terms.

11:55 am
BE

Short-term momentum – FX-driven upgrades
We upgrade our 2017E EPS by c6% on average for our UK engineering coverage
group, with c10% upgrades at many names. FX is a strong tailwind, although
countered somewhat by slightly lower growth assumptions as UBS reduces its GDP
forecasts, not just in the UK, but also in Europe/US. History shows that FX benefits are if
anything negatively correlated to sector share-price performance as the overriding
factor is organic growth and this remains low.

BE

Medium-term problems – ROIC at 15-year lows
Much discussion on the UK engineers in the last couple of years has focused on the
sustainability of peak margins. However, ROIC peaked in 2011 and has fallen
consistently since, and is now at 15-year lows for the group. We believe this reflects
managers attempting to buy growth in a slower world. While we forecast some
recovery, a low growth backdrop means we expect to remain near the 15-year trough.

BE

More selective on stocks
With absolute valuations near 15-year highs, we see more limited opportunities in the
group. We downgrade IMI to Sell, reflecting our view that the growth backdrop
remains soft for general industrials, and we cut Spirax-Sarco to Neutral. We retain Sell
ratings on Spectris and Fenner. Our preferred names are Bodycote, Vesuvius and Weir.
We view Bodycote as undervalued "quality". Vesuvius and Weir are at cyclical low
points that we think offer significant upside as they recover.

BE

Actually, before you chuck the ape at us, there was a request for something on Japan.

BE

Post Abe's landslide victory.

BE

Natixis's Kokei Iwahara argues that Japan's gone post policy.

12:00 pm
BE

These results could give an impression that the public largely supports Mr. Abe’s policies. However, this is far from reality. The approval rate for the coalition was lower than the “undecided” and “don’t know” (Chart 2). Arguably, the low turnout at about 53.5% worked in favor of the coalition. In fact, results on exit polls revealed that the unaffiliated
voters ended up preferring the oppositions, such as the Democratic Party (DP) and the Japanese Communist Party (JCP) (Chart 3). The actual result on the election could had been quite different, if the turnout were higher.

BE

(You'll have to do without the charts.)

PM

Oh, i wanted to see the Japanese Communist Party performance

12:01 pm
BE

Tough.

BE

As discussed in the previous report , the results of the election have more political implication than an economic one. Because the coalition already has a 2/3 majority at the Lower House, it can introduce economic policies without the approval of the Upper House. On the other hand, the coalition can make progresses in revising the constitution, which requires approvals from both the Lower and Upper houses with 2/3 majorities.
It is well known that PM Abe is willing to revise the constitution, particularly the war-renouncing Article 9. This could recast the Self-Defense Force (SDF) as a full-fledged military. In fact, Mr. Abe’s eagerness is deeply rooted in his grandfather ’s unfinished business to rearm Japan. However, while Komei, LDP’s coalition, is in favor of the revision of the constitution, it is clearly against in rewriting the Article 9. Furthermore, the public is largely opposed to rewriting the constitution (Chart 4), which suggests that a revision may not be supported at a national referendum. Therefore, the coalition is expected to face difficulties in building a consensus on these controversial issues. The risk is that PM Abe’s focus could shift from economic to political issues.
The coalition advocated to accelerate Abenomics during the election campaign. However, the Bank of Japan (BoJ) is running out of ammunition and the fiscal space is becoming limited, as the public debt already reached 230% of GDP in 2015. Because the low hanging fruits have been already picked, the government need to make progresses on the structural issues. Although the LDP attempts to ensure the “equal pay for equal work” principle and to introduce child care and health care programs, difficult questions on the labor market reforms and the required financial resources have remained unanswered.
Conclusion
The coalition won a landslide victory at the July Upper House election. Our view is that the results have more important political implication than an economic one. With the revisionist friends outside of the coalition, PM Abe can make progresses in revising the constitution. However, they are expected to face difficulties in building a consensus on this sensitive issue. Going forward, Abenomics will continue to dominate the economic policy arena, but the risk is economic issues taking the back seat, should Mr. Abe become obsessed with the constitutional revision.

BE

(@Boncoeur: I was putting that down mostly to Pokemon Go.)
